title: SIR | English meaning - Cambridge Dictionary
text: Meaning of sir in English Sir noun uk strong /sɜːr/ weak /sər/ us strong /sɝː/ weak /sɚ/Sir Walter (Scott) sir | American Dictionary sir noun [C] (USED TO ADDRESS) Sir | Business English Examples of sir sir Can you read us the wording of your proposed amendment, sir? From the Cambridge English Corpus One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she's dead. From the Cambridge English Corpus Forgive me, sir, consider my condition of unbearable suffering, consider my misfortune. From the Cambridge English Corpus Let go, sir, let go, sir, don't lift up the cloth of my veil! From the Cambridge English Corpus Our major issue of interest was children's spelling of words like sir. From the Cambridge English Corpus The best way send one to come and check this small thing quickly sir. From the Cambridge English Corpus His vocatives indicate this: the detachment of "sir" (2, 9), the conventional neutrality of "thou" (5), the intimacy of "my friend" (5). From the Cambridge English Corpus There must be someone in the background, sir; it can't be the cousin. From the Cambridge English Corpus Yes sir; so far as the official information is concerned, it is correct. From the Hansard archive Example from the Hansard archive.
